data.title: Caesar code
data.solution:
msg = input()
decoded = msg[0]
for letter in msg[1:]:
    decoded += chr(65 + ((ord(letter) - ord(decoded[-1]) - 1) % 26))
print(decoded[1:])

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Caesar cipher is one of the simplest and most widely known encryption techniques. But one of his general has the idea to make a tiny modification to the cipher technique.
Instead of always shifting 3 letters to the right : A -> D, B -> E, ... , Z -> C. We should shift as many letter as the previous decoded letter. Going back to the beginning of the alphabet if you past the Z.
For the first cipher shift you should use the first letter of the message which is in fact not part of the message, but only there to start the chain of decoding.

For example, if the input in AZ
First letter is a A so first shift is a 1 letter shift
Second letter is Z so decoded letter is Z shift 1 = Y
Input
Line 1 : One string msg which is the message to decipher.
Output
Line 1 : One string which is the message deciphered.
Constraints
2 ≤ length of msg ≤ 100
Example
Input
AZ
Output
Y
